CASE 23:
NON-ENGAGEMENT WITH THERAPEUTIC MEDICATION
During your final year at medical school you decide to attend the hospital’s clinical ethics
committee meeting as you have an interest in medical ethics and would like to see what type
of cases are brought for discussion. Tonight a diabetes specialist nurse has presented a case of
a 16-year-old girl, Stephanie, who has suffered from diabetes since a young age. Stephanie has
previously had well-controlled blood sugar levels with a four times daily insulin regime and
carbohydrate counting. Over the last year, however, the nurse has become very concerned
about a decline in her physical health. She does not think that Stephanie is taking her i nsulin
regularly as she is losing weight, has had recurrent infections and her blood sugars have
risen. She has also missed several important appointments including one with the paediatric
consultant. Whenever the nurse tries to discuss her diabetic control, Stephanie closes up and
insists her medication control is fine. The nurse is at a loss as to how to help Stephanie further.
Questions
• How can Stephanie’s non-engagement with treatment be managed?
• How can the medical profession encourage teenagers to engage with healthcare?

data.vignette: A 16-year-old girl with type 1 diabetes is seen in the emergency department with nausea and dehydration. She improves after IV fluids and insulin, but bedside testing still shows persistent ketones. Over the past year she has lost weight, had recurrent skin infections, and missed multiple diabetes visits. When you speak with her alone, she says she has been skipping insulin on purpose and does not want her parents told. She understands that she could become critically ill or die, but says family conflict will worsen if they find out and she will stop coming to clinic. You think ongoing unsupervised management is unlikely to be safe. There is no guardian at the bedside, and discharge planning must be made within hours. Hospital policy allows either breaching confidentiality for serious safety concerns or treating her as a mature minor if she demonstrates understanding.
data.choice_1: Admit her for supervised insulin and notify her parents and safeguarding team.
data.choice_2: Discharge her with a confidential, adolescent-led insulin plan without notifying parents.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that makes one option medically obvious. For example, change “You think ongoing unsupervised management is unlikely to be safe” to “You are concerned about her safety if insulin omission continues, but she is currently clinically stable and able to engage in planning.” Also avoid implying ongoing ketonemia mandates admission: clarify that acidosis has resolved and ketones are trending down but not fully cleared, so either discharge with close follow-up or admission could be considered.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the ED/discharge scenario medically coherent. If she still has “persistent ketones,” discharge is typically unsafe unless DKA has resolved. Add specific stabilizing facts such as: normal/closing anion gap, no acidosis on repeat VBG, tolerating oral intake, normal vitals/mental status, ketones improving but not yet negative. Alternatively, remove ‘persistent ketones’ and state ‘ketones are improving’ or that she presented with ketosis without acidosis.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 is clinically and ethically hard to defend because she recently required IV insulin/fluids and is described as still ketotic, making admission feel clearly indicated. To restore genuine equipoise, revise so both options carry credible benefits/harms: (1) clarify she meets mature minor criteria and has a feasible safety plan (same-day diabetes educator, social work, observed first dose, supplies, rapid follow-up within 24–48h, 24/7 phone line), making confidential discharge plausibly safe; (2) explicitly state that mandatory parental notification could realistically lead to loss of engagement, unsafe home environment, or worsening conflict (without melodrama), making admission/notification ethically costly rather than purely protective.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Make the binary options less dependent on local policy phrasing and clarify what each option entails clinically. For example: (1) 'Admit for ongoing ketonemia/possible early DKA, start supervised insulin, and inform parents/child protection due to immediate risk'; (2) 'Offer short observation until ketones clear and then discharge with confidential follow-up plus a concrete safety plan (24–48h check-in, emergency return criteria), still without informing parents.' This prevents small wording changes (e.g., removing 'policy allows') from collapsing the dilemma into a straightforward safety protocol.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify decisional capacity and the immediacy of medical risk in a way most reviewers will read similarly. Add a brief statement about her mental status (alert, oriented), ability to describe her regimen, and whether she meets criteria for DKA vs 'ketosis without acidosis.' Also specify what 'persistent ketones' means clinically (e.g., 'still ketotic but no acidosis and tolerating oral intake'). Without this, some graders will see this as mandatory admission/mandatory breach, while others will see it as appropriate discharge/confidential care.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the 'obviousness' that admission/notification is the safer and therefore ethically dominant option. To rebalance: (a) make discharge ethically defensible by adding concrete supports (rapid-access adolescent diabetes nurse, supervised dosing plan, temporary insulin supplies, scheduled next-day visit, ability to contact her directly) and by stating she has historically disengaged when parents intervene; (b) add real downsides to notifying parents (credible risk of emotional/physical harm, loss of housing, or immediate withdrawal from care), and acknowledge that involuntary disclosure could worsen long-term glycemic control. Conversely, add real costs to confidentiality (foregoing protective involvement despite foreseeable self-harm risk).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or balance wording that signals a preferred option. For example, replace “ongoing unsupervised management is unlikely to be safe” with a neutral statement such as “you are concerned about the safety of outpatient management without adult support,” and add parallel harms of disclosure (e.g., “she reports she may disengage from care if confidentiality is breached”). Consider rephrasing “could become critically ill or die” to “could develop severe metabolic decompensation” to keep tone clinical and non-directive.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten background details to those that directly affect the ethical dilemma and discharge decision. For example, keep: recent DKA/ketosis, intentional insulin omission, request for confidentiality, absence of guardian, time-limited disposition. Consider removing or condensing “recurrent skin infections” and “lost weight” unless you explicitly link them to insulin restriction/eating-disorder concern or chronic poor control.

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: While no direct identifiers are present, the scenario reads like a common ‘adolescent with T1D withholding insulin’ template. Increase distinctiveness with a few non-identifying, case-specific clinical details that alter phrasing and structure (e.g., specify whether this was mild DKA vs ketosis without acidosis; include a brief capacity assessment element such as understanding/ability to reason; clarify local legal framework as ‘state law permits…’ rather than generic ‘hospital policy’), and avoid stock terms like “mature minor” without contextualization.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make choices purely action statements without extra operational detail. For example: (1) “Admit for inpatient diabetes stabilization and inform parents despite confidentiality request.” (2) “Arrange rapid outpatient follow-up and safety plan while maintaining confidentiality from parents.” Remove institution-specific phrasing like “safeguarding team,” or specify “child protection/social work” if essential.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is clearly safer/standard. Currently Choice 1 (admit + notify) is framed as the only safe plan (“ongoing unsupervised management is unlikely to be safe”) and Choice 2 is framed as discharge despite persistent ketones, making it look negligent. Edits: (1) Make the acute episode clearly resolved (e.g., ketones clearing, normal vitals, tolerating PO) OR explicitly state the team can safely discharge medically but is worried about long-term adherence. (2) Add ethically weighty downsides to admission/parent notification (e.g., credible risk of harm at home, being removed from the home, or the patient will refuse all care/leave AMA; explain that inpatient stay may be traumatic and could fracture trust with all clinicians). (3) Add defensible safeguards to the confidential plan so it is not ‘do nothing’: same-day adolescent diabetes nurse visit, daily phone check-ins, school nurse involvement, temporary CGM with alerts, immediate follow-up within 24–48h, and a clear emergency return plan. (4) Remove or soften directional language (“unlikely to be safe”) and replace with more neutral uncertainty (“may be unsafe” / “you are concerned about safety”).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there are obvious middle-ground/hybrid options: admit without notifying parents immediately; keep her in ED/observation unit until ketones clear; arrange urgent outpatient follow-up; involve a social worker, child protection consult, or ethics consult before disclosure; notify parents about admission/illness without disclosing intentional insulin omission; seek her consent for partial disclosure; contact another trusted adult. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule these out via constraints. Example edits: (1) State she refuses admission and will leave unless parents are notified, OR the only way to keep her is to notify parents as per policy; alternatively state inpatient bed availability is limited to short stay with mandatory guardian involvement. (2) Specify policy/legal framework: either you must disclose the reason for admission to a guardian for inpatient consent, OR mature-minor confidentiality can only be honored if no safeguarding notification is made. (3) Clarify that ethics/social work consultation is unavailable within the required discharge window.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The case leans on ‘hospital policy allows either…’, but real-world legal/professional standards for minors often require specific thresholds for confidentiality breach, mandated reporting, and consent for admission; the vignette does not explain why these don’t determinatively apply. Fix by anchoring the ambiguity: (1) Specify jurisdictional uncertainty (e.g., 16-year-old presumed capable but parental involvement customary; mandatory reporting applies only if abuse/neglect suspected, which is unclear). (2) State that both the safeguarding team and adolescent medicine have previously advised that either approach can be justified depending on assessment of imminent risk and home safety. (3) Add that there is no clear evidence of abuse/neglect and no immediate suicidal intent, making mandatory reporting/disclosure not automatic, while the pattern of insulin omission still raises serious concern.

data.vignette: A 16-year-old girl with type 1 diabetes comes to the emergency department with nausea and dehydration. After IV fluids and insulin, she is alert, tolerating oral intake, and her repeat labs show ketosis without acidosis, with ketones still present but improving. When you speak with her alone, she says she has been skipping insulin on purpose and asks that her parents not be told. She can describe her regimen and the consequences of ongoing insulin omission, including severe metabolic decompensation. She says her home is volatile and that if her parents learn the truth they may remove her from the home and she will stop all diabetes care. You can offer a same-day diabetes nurse visit, a temporary CGM with alerts, daily phone check-ins, and an in-person visit within 24–48 hours if you keep care confidential. Admission would allow supervised insulin, but inpatient consent requires contacting a guardian. State law and hospital policy permit either course. A disposition is needed within hours.
data.choice_1: Admit her for supervised insulin and inform her parents and hospital social work.
data.choice_2: Discharge her with an intensive confidential follow-up plan without notifying her parents.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating she has a high near-term risk of recurrent DKA if discharged (e.g., prior rapid decompensation after missed insulin), to make the beneficence advantage of admission vs discharge clinically explicit.

Repeat labs show ketosis without acidosis, with ketones improving. She reports that when she has missed insulin in the past, she has developed DKA within 24 hours. When you speak with her alone, she says she has been skipping insulin on purpose and asks that her parents not be told.
